The crimson pool spread across the concrete floor of the warehouse, and for the first time in her career, Wanjiku Mwangi felt her stomach lurch. Her hands trembled as she dropped the knife, the metallic clang echoing through the empty space. The sight that had once brought her a twisted satisfaction now filled her with overwhelming nausea.

She had been Nairobi's most feared assassin for seven years, moving through the shadows of the sprawling city like a ghost. Her reputation was built on precision, on the ability to eliminate targets without hesitation or remorse. Politicians, business rivals, unfaithful spouses - she had dispatched them all with the same cold efficiency that had earned her the nickname "Nyoka ya Usiku" - the Night Serpent.

But something had changed three weeks ago. The first sign came during what should have been a routine elimination in Westlands. As she watched the life drain from her target's eyes, an unexpected wave of revulsion had washed over her. She had attributed it to exhaustion, perhaps something she had eaten. Now, staring at the fresh corpse before her, she could no longer deny the truth.

Wanjiku stumbled backward, pressing her palm against the rough brick wall to steady herself. Her client, a wealthy businessman who had discovered his partner's embezzlement, would expect confirmation of the job's completion. But she couldn't look at the body again, couldn't bear to see what she had done.

The killer who had once dissected her victims with surgical precision now couldn't stomach the sight of a paper cut.

She fumbled for her phone with shaking fingers, typing a brief message to her handler: "Job complete. Payment as discussed." The lie came easily, but the tremor in her hands betrayed her inner turmoil. She had to get out of there before the smell of copper and death overwhelmed her completely.

Wanjiku pulled her black hoodie over her head and slipped out through the service entrance. The cool Nairobi evening air hit her face, providing momentary relief from the suffocating atmosphere of the warehouse. She walked quickly through the industrial district, her footsteps echoing off the concrete walls of shuttered factories and storage facilities.

Her apartment in Kilimani felt like a sanctuary when she finally reached it two hours later. She had taken three matatus and walked several kilometers to ensure she wasn't followed, a paranoia that had kept her alive in a profession where trust was a luxury few could afford. The small one-bedroom flat was spartanly furnished - a bed, a desk, a single chair, and a kitchenette that she rarely used. On the walls hung no photographs, no personal mementos. Wanjiku Mwangi, the person, barely existed. Only the Night Serpent was real.

She poured herself three fingers of Tusker whiskey and sat on the edge of her bed, trying to make sense of what was happening to her. In the bathroom mirror, she examined her reflection - a woman in her early thirties with sharp cheekbones and eyes that had seen too much. Her grandmother would have said she was being visited by the spirits of her victims, that their restless souls were demanding justice. But Wanjiku had never believed in such things. She dealt in the tangible world of contracts and corpses, of money transferred to offshore accounts and problems permanently solved.

The next morning brought no relief. She attempted to eat breakfast but found herself unable to swallow after accidentally biting her tongue and tasting blood. The metallic flavor sent her rushing to the toilet, where she dry-heaved until her ribs ached. This was more than inconvenient - it was potentially fatal. In her line of work, hesitation meant death, and weakness invited enemies.

Her phone buzzed with a text from Marcus Okello, her primary handler and the closest thing she had to a friend in this business. "New job. High value target. Interested?" Under normal circumstances, she would have responded immediately with her fee structure. Instead, she stared at the message for twenty minutes before typing back: "Need a few days to handle personal matters."

Marcus's reply came within seconds: "Personal matters? Since when do you have a personal life, Nyoka? This client is willing to pay triple your usual rate."

Triple her usual rate would be enough to retire comfortably, perhaps disappear to some beach in Zanzibar where no one knew her real name. But first, she would have to complete the job, and that meant confronting whatever psychological barrier had suddenly erected itself in her mind. She typed back: "One week. Then we talk."

The days that followed were a study in frustration. Wanjiku attempted to desensitize herself by visiting a butcher shop in Eastleigh, thinking that exposure to animal blood might help her overcome her aversion. Instead, she fainted in the middle of the shop, coming to consciousness on the floor surrounded by concerned Somali women who pressed cups of sweet tea into her hands and asked if she needed a doctor.

She tried watching violent movies, hoping that fictional blood might serve as a bridge back to comfort with the real thing. The opening scene of a popular American action film sent her running to the bathroom again. Even the evening news, with its inevitable coverage of Nairobi's daily violence, became impossible to watch.

By the end of the week, Wanjiku had to admit defeat. She met Marcus at a small café in Karen, far from the prying ears of downtown. He was a thin man with prematurely gray hair and wire-rimmed glasses that made him look more like an accountant than someone who brokered death for a living. Which, she supposed, was exactly the point.

"You look terrible," Marcus said without preamble, stirring sugar into his coffee. "When's the last time you slept?"

"I need out of the game," Wanjiku said quietly. "At least temporarily."

Marcus set down his spoon with deliberate care. "Out? Wanjiku, you don't just take a sabbatical from this profession. You know that."

"I can't do it anymore. Something's wrong with me."

"Define wrong."

She told him about the blood, about the nausea and the fear that now accompanied every job. Marcus listened without interruption, his expression growing more concerned with each detail.

"Have you seen a doctor?" he asked when she finished.

"What am I supposed to tell them? That I'm a killer who's suddenly developed a conscience?"

"You tell them you're having panic attacks. You tell them you work in a hospital and developed a phobia after a traumatic incident. You lie, Wanjiku, like you've been doing your entire adult life."

She knew he was right, but the thought of admitting weakness to anyone, even a doctor bound by confidentiality, felt like signing her own death warrant. In their world, vulnerability was blood in the water, and there were always sharks circling.

"I need time to figure this out," she said.

"Time is a luxury you don't have. Do you know who requested you specifically for this job?"

Wanjiku shook her head.

"Dr. Amara Ochieng."

The name hit her like a physical blow. Dr. Amara Ochieng - brilliant scientist, tech entrepreneur, and the woman who had systematically destroyed Wanjiku's life seven years ago. They had been roommates at the University of Nairobi, both studying chemistry, both ambitious and driven. Amara had been everything Wanjiku was not - wealthy, connected, effortlessly charming. She had also been a thief and a liar who had stolen Wanjiku's research on synthetic compounds and used it as the foundation for her own pharmaceutical empire.

When Wanjiku had tried to expose her, Amara's family connections had ensured that Wanjiku was expelled for academic dishonesty instead. The irony was so perfect it was almost beautiful. Within six months, Wanjiku had found her way into Nairobi's criminal underground, trading her knowledge of chemistry for a education in murder.

"She wants me to kill someone?" Wanjiku asked.

"She wants you dead, obviously. The question is why now, after all these years."

Marcus slid a manila envelope across the table. "This might explain it."

Inside were newspaper clippings and printed articles about Dr. Ochieng's latest venture - a private space exploration company called Uhuru Aerospace. According to the reports, she had successfully tested a prototype rocket and was preparing for Kenya's first privately-funded space mission. The Kenyan government had pledged support, and international investors were lining up to fund her ambitious plans.

"She's actually going to space?" Wanjiku murmured, studying a photograph of Amara standing beside a sleek white rocket in what appeared to be a facility somewhere outside Nairobi.

"Looks that way. Maybe she's worried that her past misdeeds might resurface now that she's in the international spotlight. Dead people can't contradict her version of events."

Wanjiku closed the envelope and leaned back in her chair. The cosmic joke was not lost on her - just as she was losing her ability to kill, the one person she had always dreamed of eliminating had delivered herself as a target. And she was offering triple the usual rate to have herself murdered, apparently unaware that she was hiring her old roommate turned assassin.

"What's the timeline?" Wanjiku asked.

"Two weeks. She wants it done before the official launch announcement."

Two weeks to overcome a phobia that seemed to be getting worse by the day. Two weeks to prepare for a confrontation seven years in the making. Two weeks to decide if revenge was worth risking everything she had built.

"I'll take the job," she said.

Marcus raised an eyebrow. "Are you sure? If you hesitate at the crucial moment..."

"I won't hesitate. Not with her."

But even as she spoke the words, Wanjiku felt doubt gnawing at her resolve. Amara Ochieng had always been able to bring out the worst in her, to make her act impulsively and emotionally. Now she was proposing to face her greatest enemy while battling a psychological condition that had already compromised her effectiveness.**Chapter 1: The Scent of Fear**

The morning after accepting the contract, Wanjiku stood in her bathroom gripping the porcelain sink until her knuckles went white. In the mirror, dark circles shadowed her eyes, and her usually steady hands betrayed the turmoil churning beneath her carefully maintained facade. She had spent the night researching Amara's current life, poring over social media profiles, news articles, and security footage she had acquired through her network of contacts in Nairobi's digital underworld. The woman who had once shared late-night study sessions and dreams of changing the world had transformed into something almost unrecognizable - a polished corporate executive whose smile never quite reached her eyes.

Dr. Amara Ochieng now lived in a fortified compound in Runda, complete with private security, surveillance cameras, and the kind of electronic countermeasures that suggested she had made enemies beyond just former roommates. Her daily routine was meticulously planned and varied just enough to frustrate potential threats. She traveled between her Westlands office, the aerospace facility in Kiambu, and her home in armored vehicles with professional drivers who had military backgrounds. Getting close to her would require weeks of careful planning, the kind of patient surveillance that had made Wanjiku's reputation in the first place.

But surveillance meant watching, and watching meant seeing, and the thought of blood - even the possibility of blood - still made her stomach rebel against her will. She had tried again that morning to desensitize herself, purchasing a piece of raw beef from a local butcher and attempting to handle it without gloves. The result had been another humiliating episode of dry heaving over her kitchen sink while the meat lay abandoned on her counter, attracting flies in the afternoon heat.

Her phone buzzed with a message from Marcus: "Target will be attending charity gala tomorrow night. Hotel Intercontinental. Black tie event for children's cancer research. Ironic, considering." He was right about the irony - Amara using her stolen research fortune to fund medical research while simultaneously trying to eliminate the woman whose work had made it all possible. The gala would provide an opportunity to observe her target's security protocols and potentially identify vulnerabilities, but it also meant venturing into Nairobi's elite social circles where Wanjiku would be completely out of her element.

The Night Serpent was comfortable in shadows and abandoned warehouses, not cocktail parties filled with politicians and business leaders who might recognize her face from wanted posters or police briefings. She would need to construct an entirely new identity for the evening, complete with backstory and credentials that would survive casual scrutiny. More challenging still, she would need to control her physical reactions if conversation turned to topics that might trigger her newly developed phobia.

Wanjiku spent the afternoon shopping for appropriate attire in the boutiques of Sarit Centre, a task made complicated by her complete inexperience with formal wear and her growing anxiety about the evening ahead. The saleswoman at an upscale dress shop eyed her with barely concealed suspicion as she fumbled through racks of evening gowns, clearly out of place among the wealthy Kenyan women who typically frequented such establishments. Eventually, she settled on a simple black dress that could pass for elegant while allowing freedom of movement should circumstances require a quick exit.

The transformation back in her apartment was both physical and psychological. She styled her usually unkempt hair into an elegant chignon, applied makeup with the careful precision she normally reserved for disguises, and practiced walking in heels until her feet ached. In the mirror, she barely recognized herself - the hardened killer had been replaced by someone who might believably claim to work in international development or NGO management. She had selected the cover identity of Dr. Sarah Kimani, a consultant specializing in technology transfer for African development projects, complete with business cards printed that afternoon and a hastily constructed LinkedIn profile.

As evening fell over Nairobi, Wanjiku called a taxi rather than risk taking matatus while dressed for formal event. The driver, perhaps accustomed to ferrying wealthy passengers to social functions, maintained professional silence during the journey through the city's congested streets. She used the time to review her mental notes about the other attendees, cross-referencing faces with names and potential connections to her target. The guest list had been surprisingly easy to obtain through a contact who worked in event planning - apparently, charity galas were less concerned with security than with publicity.

The Hotel Intercontinental blazed with lights as they approached, its circular driveway crowded with expensive vehicles disgorging elegantly dressed passengers. Wanjiku paid the taxi driver and joined the stream of guests flowing toward the entrance, her heart rate elevated but manageable. She had attended far more dangerous gatherings in her professional capacity, though none that required her to maintain pleasant conversation while fighting the urge to flee at the first sign of anything red and viscous.

Inside, the ballroom had been transformed into something from a fairy tale, with white linens, crystal chandeliers, and elaborate floral arrangements that probably cost more than most Kenyans earned in a year. Waiters circulated with trays of champagne and hors d'oeuvres while a small orchestra provided background music. The crowd was exactly what she had expected - government officials, business leaders, diplomats, and the kind of wealthy socialites who treated charity work as both social obligation and networking opportunity.

Wanjiku accepted a glass of champagne from a passing waiter and began her reconnaissance, moving through the crowd with practiced casualness while scanning faces and noting security arrangements. She spotted several individuals who were clearly protection details rather than guests - men and women who stood at strategic positions, their eyes constantly moving, their jackets cut to conceal weapons. The hotel's own security was also enhanced for the evening, with additional personnel stationed at exits and entrances.

Then she saw her, and seven years collapsed into nothing.**Chapter 2: Ghosts in Crystal**

Amara Ochieng stood near the center of the ballroom like a queen holding court, surrounded by a constellation of admirers who hung on her every word. The years had been kind to her in the way they often were to those born with advantages - her skin glowed with the health that expensive treatments and minimal stress could provide, and her designer gown hugged a figure maintained by personal trainers and nutritionists. She gestured elegantly as she spoke, her voice carrying just enough to reach Wanjiku's position twenty feet away, discussing her upcoming space mission with the breathless enthusiasm of someone who had never been told that her dreams were impossible.

What struck Wanjiku most forcefully was not how much Amara had changed, but how little. The same calculating intelligence flickered behind her eyes, the same subtle manipulation in how she positioned herself to ensure she remained the center of attention. Even her laugh was identical - a musical sound that had once made Wanjiku feel included in something special, before she learned it was often deployed as a weapon to make others feel excluded. Standing there in her stolen success, Amara embodied everything that had driven Wanjiku into the darkness seven years ago, every injustice that had transformed a promising chemistry student into Nairobi's most feared assassin.

The champagne glass trembled slightly in Wanjiku's hand as she forced herself to look away and continue her surveillance. She needed to think like the Night Serpent, not like the broken girl who had been expelled from university. Professional assessment revealed that Amara's security detail consisted of at least four visible operatives positioned at cardinal points around her location, with likely additional backup stationed throughout the venue. They were good - alert without being obvious, blending into the crowd while maintaining clear sight lines to their principal. Getting close enough for a traditional elimination would require significant preparation and probably considerable collateral damage.

A waiter appeared at her elbow offering canapés from a silver tray, and Wanjiku's stomach clenched as she noticed the small garnish of what appeared to be red pepper sauce on several pieces. The crimson drops looked uncomfortably similar to blood in the ballroom's golden lighting, and she quickly shook her head and moved away before her physical reaction could betray her. This was exactly what she had feared - even the suggestion of her phobia's trigger was enough to compromise her ability to function normally. How could she possibly complete a contract when the sight of ketchup made her nauseous?

She positioned herself near a marble pillar that provided both concealment and a clear view of Amara's location, then began the careful process of eavesdropping on conversations that might reveal useful intelligence. The guests were discussing typical high-society concerns - property investments in Karen and Runda, children's admissions to international schools, vacation plans for Dubai and London. But scattered throughout the mundane chatter were references to government contracts, mining concessions, and the kind of political maneuvering that kept Kenya's elite wealthy while the majority struggled with unemployment and rising costs of living.

"Dr. Ochieng is really quite remarkable," said a woman standing nearby, her voice carrying the affected accent that some wealthy Kenyans adopted after studying abroad. "To think that a Kenyan company might actually reach space before the South Africans or Nigerians. It would put us on the map in such a significant way." Her companion, a portly man in an expensive suit that strained against his considerable bulk, nodded enthusiastically while examining the contents of his whiskey glass. "The government contracts alone will be worth billions once she proves the technology works. I heard from someone at the Treasury that they're already planning to route all satellite launches through Uhuru Aerospace within five years."

This was new information that Marcus had not included in his briefing. If Amara's space venture was positioned to become Kenya's exclusive launch provider, the financial implications were staggering. More importantly from Wanjiku's perspective, it suggested that her former roommate had made the kind of enemies who might be willing to pay premium rates to prevent that monopoly from forming. The client offering triple her usual fee might not be motivated by personal grievances at all, but by the calculated desire to eliminate a business threat worth potentially hundreds of millions of dollars.

Wanjiku moved closer to Amara's circle, using a group of animated diplomats as cover while she strained to hear the conversation. Up close, she could see details that photographs had not captured - the barely visible scar on Amara's left hand from a chemistry lab accident during their second year, the nervous habit she still had of touching her earring when she was lying, the way her eyes constantly scanned the room even while appearing to focus intently on whoever was speaking to her. These were the observations that separated professional killers from amateurs, the intimate knowledge of a target's unconscious behaviors that could mean the difference between success and catastrophic failure.

"The launch is scheduled for six months from now," Amara was saying to a distinguished gentleman who carried himself with the bearing of someone accustomed to significant authority. "We'll be putting a communications satellite into orbit for the East African Communications Consortium, but more importantly, we'll be proving that African nations don't need to depend on European or American companies for space access. It's about technological sovereignty as much as commercial opportunity." The man nodded approvingly, though Wanjiku noticed his eyes held the calculating expression of someone evaluating profit potential rather than patriotic pride.

A burst of laughter from the group drew unwanted attention, and Wanjiku realized she had moved too close. One of Amara's security operatives, a tall woman with the alert posture of former military, had noticed her proximity and was studying her with professional interest. Making eye contact would only heighten suspicion, so Wanjiku smoothly turned away and began walking toward the bar, maintaining the casual pace of someone seeking a drink refill rather than fleeing surveillance. Her years of operational experience had taught her that sudden movements were far more likely to attract attention than deliberately normal behavior.

At the bar, she ordered another champagne and used the mirrored wall behind the bartender to monitor whether the security operative was still watching her. The woman had returned her attention to scanning the broader crowd, but Wanjiku noticed she had shifted position slightly to maintain a better view of the area where the suspicious guest had been standing. This level of vigilance suggested that Amara's security concerns were based on more than general paranoia - someone had made specific threats, or intelligence indicated elevated risk during this particular time period.

The evening's program began with speeches from various dignitaries and benefactors, providing Wanjiku with an opportunity to study Amara's behavior during moments when she believed herself unobserved. Even while applauding politely or maintaining appropriate expressions of interest, Amara's body language revealed constant tension. Her shoulders remained rigid despite her relaxed posture, and her eyes continued their restless movement around the room. Most tellingly, she kept one hand positioned near her evening bag in a way that suggested it contained something more significant than makeup and car keys - possibly a panic button or personal protection device.

When Amara finally took the podium to address the gathering, Wanjiku felt the full force of her charisma for the first time in seven years. Her former roommate had always possessed the ability to command attention, but success and confidence had refined that natural talent into something almost magnetic. She spoke passionately about the children's cancer research that would benefit from the evening's fundraising, weaving personal anecdotes with statistics in a way that had the audience completely engaged. Several people were discretely wiping away tears by the time she finished, and the applause was thunderous and sustained.

But Wanjiku heard something else in the speech - subtle references to perseverance through adversity, to overcoming those who would tear down others' achievements, to the importance of supporting African innovators against foreign competitors who might use underhanded tactics to maintain their dominance. The language was carefully neutral, but to someone who knew Amara's history, it sounded distinctly like the words of someone who feared that past sins might threaten current success. She was sending a message to potential threats, using the public forum to position herself as a patriotic pioneer whose elimination would be an attack on Kenya itself.

As the formal program concluded and guests began moving toward the silent auction displays, Wanjiku made her decision to attempt direct contact. It was risky, potentially catastrophic if Amara recognized her, but she needed to understand her target's current psychological state and security awareness. The best assassinations were built on intimate knowledge of the victim's fears and expectations, and no amount of surveillance could replace a face-to-face assessment of Amara's mental condition.

She approached during a momentary gap in the crowd around Amara, timing her movement to coincide with a distraction as waiters began clearing tables nearby. "Dr. Ochieng, what a inspiring speech," she said, extending her hand with a confident smile. "Dr. Sarah Kimani, I work with technology transfer programs for the African Development Bank. I'd love to discuss potential collaboration opportunities for your aerospace initiative." The lie rolled off her tongue with practiced ease, supported by the business cards and background research that would survive casual verification.

Amara's handshake was firm and brief, her eyes quickly scanning Wanjiku's face with the automatic assessment of someone accustomed to networking with strangers. For a terrifying moment, Wanjiku thought she saw a flicker of recognition, but then Amara's professional smile broadened and she launched into what was obviously a practiced response to similar overtures. "Thank you so much, Dr. Kimani. We're always interested in partnerships that can help African space technology reach its full potential. Are you familiar with our launch capabilities?" As she spoke, Amara's hand moved unconsciously to touch her earring - the nervous gesture that meant she was evaluating whether this conversation might be beneficial or threatening.

Standing less than two feet from her target, breathing the same air scented with expensive perfume and floral arrangements, Wanjiku felt a strange disconnection from reality. This woman had destroyed her life, stolen her work, and was now unknowingly paying for her own assassination while making small talk about development banking. The cosmic absurdity of the situation was matched only by its tragic inevitability - they were both trapped in roles that seven years of choices had made inescapable. Amara could no more stop being the successful executive protecting her empire than Wanjiku could stop being the killer hired to destroy it.

"I'm particularly interested in the applications for satellite communications across rural East Africa," Wanjiku continued, maintaining her cover identity while studying every micro-expression that crossed Amara's face. "The potential for connecting remote communities is extraordinary, but I imagine the security challenges must be significant given the strategic importance of the technology." It was a calculated probe, designed to gauge how much of Amara's current stress was related to business threats versus personal ones.

Amara's response confirmed Wanjiku's suspicions about the source of her heightened security measures. "Security is definitely a major consideration," she said, her voice dropping slightly and her eyes making a quick sweep of their immediate surroundings. "There are parties who would prefer to see African space capabilities remain limited to avoid competition with established providers. We've had to take precautions that go well beyond normal business practices." The admission was more revealing than Amara probably intended, confirming that the threats she faced were substantial enough to require the kind of protection usually reserved for government officials or controversial public figures.

Their conversation was interrupted by the arrival of a man Wanjiku recognized from newspaper photos as a prominent cabinet minister, flanked by his own security detail and clearly expecting immediate access to Amara's attention. She gracefully excused herself from their discussion, pressing a business card into Wanjiku's hand while promising to follow up about potential collaboration opportunities. As she turned away to greet the minister, Wanjiku caught a final glimpse of her profile and felt a complex mixture of emotions that had no place in a professional assessment - anger, sadness, nostalgia, and underneath it all, a profound sense of waste at how differently their lives might have unfolded.

The business card was expensive stock with subtle embossing, but more importantly, it contained Amara's direct office number and email address rather than generic corporate contact information. This suggested either exceptional trust in a complete stranger or, more likely, the reflexive networking behavior of someone who had built her career on cultivating useful relationships. Either way, it provided Wanjiku with additional avenues for surveillance and potential access that had not existed before their brief encounter.

She remained at the gala for another hour, continuing her reconnaissance while processing the intelligence gathered during their conversation. Amara's security team maintained their vigilance but showed no signs of having identified her as a threat, and the other guests continued their elaborate social rituals without apparent awareness that a professional killer was moving among them. The normalcy of it all was perhaps the most disturbing aspect of the entire evening - how easily violence could masquerade as civility, how thin the veneer was between polite society and the brutal realities that lurked just beneath its surface.**Chapter 3: The Weight of Memory**

The journey back to her apartment in Kilimani took place in a haze of conflicting thoughts and suppressed memories that Wanjiku struggled to compartmentalize. The taxi driver, perhaps sensing his passenger's desire for silence, navigated the late-night streets without attempting conversation, leaving her alone with the echoes of Amara's voice and the phantom sensation of her former roommate's handshake. The brief physical contact had triggered a flood of recollections that she had spent years carefully burying - late nights in their shared dormitory room discussing theoretical applications of synthetic compounds, collaborative study sessions that had stretched until dawn, the gradual evolution of academic rivalry into something that had felt almost like friendship until betrayal revealed its true nature.

By the time she reached her building, Wanjiku's hands were trembling again, though whether from residual adrenaline or emotional overload remained unclear. She climbed the three flights of stairs to her apartment with leaden feet, each step requiring conscious effort as her mind replayed fragments of the evening's surveillance. The professional part of her consciousness methodically catalogued useful intelligence - security patterns, potential vulnerabilities, psychological indicators that might inform tactical planning. But underneath that analytical process, deeper currents of memory and emotion threatened to undermine the careful emotional distance that had made her career possible.

Inside her spartanly furnished living space, Wanjiku poured herself a generous measure of whiskey and sat heavily in the single chair that constituted her apartment's entire seating arrangement. The elegant black dress felt suddenly constricting, a costume that had served its purpose but now seemed to mock her with its pretense of respectability. She had spent the evening among Nairobi's elite, discussing development initiatives and technological sovereignty while planning the murder of someone who had once shared her dreams of using chemistry to improve the world. The cognitive dissonance was exhausting in ways that physical violence had never been.

She retrieved her laptop and began transcribing her observations into the encrypted files where she maintained operational records, forcing herself to focus on tactical details rather than emotional responses. Amara's security detail consisted of at least six professionals, probably former military or intelligence operatives based on their positioning and movement patterns. The principal maintained elevated awareness of her surroundings even during social interactions, suggesting either specific threat intelligence or generalized paranoia based on previous incidents. Her daily routine involved movement between three primary locations with variable timing and routes, indicating professional security consultation rather than amateur precautions.

But as Wanjiku typed, she found herself including details that had no tactical relevance - the way Amara's laugh still carried the same musical quality that had once made her feel special, the nervous earring gesture that revealed underlying stress despite outward confidence, the careful way she had positioned herself to ensure optimal lighting during conversations with potential benefactors or collaborators. These observations belonged to someone who had once cared about Amara Ochieng as a person rather than assessed her as a target, and their presence in what should have been a clinical operational analysis suggested dangerous emotional compromise.

Her phone buzzed with a message from Marcus: "How did the reconnaissance go? Any useful intelligence?" The question was routine professional follow-up, but Wanjiku hesitated before responding, uncertain how much of her evening's observations would be useful versus personally compromising. She settled on a brief summary of security arrangements and facility layout, omitting her direct contact with the target and the psychological turbulence that had resulted from their conversation. Marcus was skilled at reading between the lines of her reports, and admitting emotional involvement would likely trigger protective protocols that could complicate or terminate the contract entirely.

Sleep proved elusive despite her exhaustion, as her mind continued processing the implications of what she had learned at the gala. Amara's space venture represented more than personal success or even patriotic achievement - it was potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars in government contracts and international partnerships. The kind of money that could motivate powerful interests to eliminate obstacles through any means necessary, including hiring Nairobi's most expensive assassin. But the client's willingness to pay triple her usual rate suggested urgency or desperation that went beyond routine business competition, implying personal stakes that transformed commercial rivalry into something more dangerous.

The following morning brought no relief from her psychological struggles, as Wanjiku discovered that even her usual breakfast routine had been compromised by her growing phobia. The simple act of preparing scrambled eggs became impossible when she accidentally broke the yolk and saw the yellow liquid spreading across her plate like some bizarre alternative to blood. The visual similarity was enough to trigger the same nauseous response that had plagued her for weeks, leaving her dry-heaving over her kitchen sink while perfectly edible food congealed in the morning heat.

She forced herself to review the tactical challenges that Amara's elimination would present, hoping that professional focus might overcome personal weakness. The target's primary residence in Runda was essentially a fortress, complete with walls, electronic surveillance, and roving security patrols that would make traditional infiltration extremely difficult. The Westlands office building offered better access opportunities but higher potential for collateral damage and witness complications. The aerospace facility in Kiambu was isolated enough to minimize civilian casualties but probably had the most sophisticated security arrangements given the sensitive nature of the technology being developed there.

Each potential approach required specific equipment and planning that would normally take weeks to execute properly, but the two-week timeline imposed by the client's urgency meant accepting higher risks and lower probability of successful exfiltration. Under normal circumstances, Wanjiku would have recommended extending the operational window to allow for proper preparation, but normal circumstances had never included personal history with the target or psychological barriers that compromised her fundamental capabilities as a professional killer.

Her laptop chimed with an incoming email that made her stomach clench with anticipation and dread in equal measure. The sender was listed as Dr. Amara Ochieng, and the subject line read "Development Banking Collaboration - Follow Up." For several minutes, Wanjiku stared at the message without opening it, knowing that any communication from her target would further complicate an already compromised operational environment. Professional doctrine suggested deleting the email without reading it, maintaining strict separation between surveillance activities and personal engagement. But the same curiosity that had once driven her scientific ambitions made ignoring Amara's outreach psychologically impossible.

The email's content was professionally written and carefully neutral, expressing interest in discussing potential partnerships between Uhuru Aerospace and international development organizations. Amara had clearly researched the fictional Dr. Sarah Kimani's supposed background, as she referenced specific African Development Bank initiatives that would require significant knowledge to identify. Most concerning from an operational security perspective, she had suggested a face-to-face meeting at her Westlands office within the next few days, ostensibly to explore collaborative opportunities that could benefit both organizations.

This unexpected development presented both extraordinary opportunity and unprecedented danger for Wanjiku's mission. Access to Amara's office would provide detailed intelligence about security arrangements, daily routines, and potential vulnerabilities that no amount of external surveillance could reveal. But maintaining her fictional identity through an extended professional meeting would require preparation and performance skills that went far beyond her usual operational requirements. More troubling still, spending additional time in Amara's presence might further compromise her psychological state at precisely the moment when emotional stability was most crucial.

She spent the afternoon researching actual African Development Bank programs and personnel, creating a deeper foundation for her cover identity that could survive more detailed scrutiny. The work was tedious and nerve-wracking, requiring her to absorb complex information about development economics and technology transfer policies that bore no resemblance to her actual areas of expertise. But the intellectual challenge also provided temporary distraction from her growing anxiety about the operational timeline and her persistent inability to tolerate even fictional depictions of violence or bloodshed.

Marcus called as she was practicing responses to potential questions about development banking methodology, his voice carrying the slightly strained tone that suggested he was dealing with pressure from clients or superiors. The crimson pool spread across the concrete floor of the warehouse, and for the first time in her career, Wanjiku Mwangi felt her stomach lurch. She had been Nairobi's most feared assassin for seven years, moving through the shadows of the sprawling city like a ghost. Her reputation was built on precision, on the ability to eliminate targets without hesitation or remorse. Politicians, business rivals, unfaithful spouses - she had dispatched them all with the same cold efficiency that had earned her the nickname "Nyoka ya Usiku" - the Night Serpent.

But something had changed three weeks ago. The first sign came during what should have been a routine elimination in Westlands. As she watched the life drain from her target's eyes, an unexpected wave of revulsion had washed over her. She had attributed it to exhaustion, perhaps something she had eaten. Now, staring at the fresh corpse before her, she could no longer deny the truth.

Wanjiku stumbled backward, pressing her palm against the rough brick wall to steady herself. Her client, a wealthy businessman who had discovered his partner's embezzlement, would expect confirmation of the job's completion. But she couldn't look at the body again, couldn't bear to see what she had done.

The killer who had once dissected her victims with surgical precision now couldn't stomach the sight of a paper cut.

She fumbled for her phone with shaking fingers, typing a brief message to her handler: "Job complete. Payment as discussed." The lie came easily, but the tremor in her hands betrayed her inner turmoil. She had to get out of there before the smell of copper and death overwhelmed her completely.

Wanjiku pulled her black hoodie over her head and slipped out through the service entrance. The cool Nairobi evening air hit her face, providing momentary relief from the suffocating atmosphere of the warehouse. She walked quickly through the industrial district, her footsteps echoing off the concrete walls of shuttered factories and storage facilities.

Her apartment in Kilimani felt like a sanctuary when she finally reached it two hours later. She had taken three matatus and walked several kilometers to ensure she wasn't followed, a paranoia that had kept her alive in a profession where trust was a luxury few could afford. The small one-bedroom flat was spartanly furnished - a bed, a desk, a single chair, and a kitchenette that she rarely used. On the walls hung no photographs, no personal mementos. Wanjiku Mwangi, the person, barely existed. Only the Night Serpent was real.

She poured herself three fingers of Tusker whiskey and sat on the edge of her bed, trying to make sense of what was happening to her. In the bathroom mirror, she examined her reflection - a woman in her early thirties with sharp cheekbones and eyes that had seen too much. Her grandmother would have said she was being visited by the spirits of her victims, that their restless souls were demanding justice. But Wanjiku had never believed in such things. She dealt in the tangible world of contracts and corpses, of money transferred to offshore accounts and problems permanently solved.

The next morning brought no relief. She attempted to eat breakfast but found herself unable to swallow after accidentally biting her tongue and tasting blood. The metallic flavor sent her rushing to the toilet, where she dry-heaved until her ribs ached. This was more than inconvenient - it was potentially fatal. In her line of work, hesitation meant death, and weakness invited enemies.

Her phone buzzed with a text from Marcus Okello, her primary handler and the closest thing she had to a friend in this business. "New job. High value target. Interested?"
